channel.title: NYT > World News
channel.copyright: Copyright 2022 The New York Times Company

item.title: No Respite for Ukrainian Civilians Despite Pause in Russia’s Advance
item.description: Missiles struck at least 10 urban centers in Donetsk Province, where Russia is shifting its focus. In one apartment block, the death toll rose to 30. Russia is seeking surveillance drones from Iran, Biden’s national security adviser said.
item.dc:creator: The New York Times
item.media:credit: Mauricio Lima for The New York Times

item.title: Ukrainian Medic’s Months in Russian Cell: Cold, Dirty and Used as a Prop
item.description: Yulia Paievska was already well known in Ukraine when she was captured, but the trauma she describes has made her a symbol of bravery and sacrifice.
item.dc:creator: Valerie Hopkins
item.category: Human Rights and Human Rights Violations
item.media:credit: Emile Ducke for The New York Times
item.media:description: Yulia Paievska in Kyiv, Ukraine, where she has been recuperating from months of Russian captivity.

item.title: Where Mantras Trump Medicine, Vaccines Are a ‘Violation’
item.description: The Baduy, an Indigenous group in Indonesia, believe that vaccinations are impure, and unnecessary, and that their beliefs protect them. To skeptics, they note their Covid death toll: zero.
item.dc:creator: Muktita Suhartono and Ulet Ifansasti
item.media:credit: Ulet Ifansasti for The New York Times
item.media:description: Carrying durian fruit past rice barns on the way to the nearest market. All Baduy are taught to abide by the principle that the natural world is not to be harmed.

item.title: ‘There’s Nothing’: Scarcity Deepens Desperation in Sri Lanka
item.description: The island nation was once an economic hope, with a growing middle class. Now many people are living on the edge, unable to buy even the basics.
item.dc:creator: Emily Schmall
item.media:credit: Atul Loke for The New York Times
item.media:description: A line for fuel in May in Colombo, the capital. The government has imposed rationing, and motorists can wait for days to fill their tanks.

item.title: Cambridge Opens an Inquiry After Student Deaths
item.description: One of the deaths is confirmed to have been suicide and the others are suspected of being suicides. The university is working with the National Health Service to investigate.
item.dc:creator: Cora Engelbrecht
item.media:credit: Mary Turner for The New York Times
item.media:description: Cambridge University’s King’s College last year.

item.title: Security Forces in China Attack Protesters Seeking Frozen Funds
item.description: After a rare mass demonstration, bank depositors demanding their money back were beaten, kicked to the ground and dragged away in the city of Zhengzhou.
item.dc:creator: Zixu Wang and Austin Ramzy

item.title: Rivals Vying to Replace Johnson Are Diverse in Background, Not in Plans
item.description: The Conservatives running to be Britain’s prime minister include women and people of non-European descent, but they sound a lot alike: They like Brexit and want to cut taxes.
item.dc:creator: Mark Landler and Stephen Castle
item.media:description: Rishi Sunak, who resigned as chancellor of the Exchequer, is a contender for prime minister.

item.title: Russia Repeatedly Strikes Ukraine’s Civilians. There’s Always an Excuse.
item.description: The Kremlin’s explanations have sometimes satisfied the Russian people, but they fall apart under closer scrutiny abroad.
item.dc:creator: Daniel Victor and Ivan Nechepurenko
item.media:credit: Finbarr O’Reilly for The New York Times
item.media:description: Examining the wreckage of a complex damaged by Russian bombardment in May in the center of the city of Kharkiv in eastern Ukraine.

item.title: Suspect in Abe Shooting Held a ‘Grudge.’ Scrutiny Falls on a Church.
item.description: The Unification Church, with links to conservative political parties worldwide, said Monday that the mother of the man charged in Shinzo Abe’s death was a member.
item.dc:creator: Ben Dooley and Hisako Ueno
item.media:description: Tetsuya Yamagami, who was charged in the fatal shooting of Shinzo Abe on Friday in Nara, Japan.

item.title: A Year After Mass Protest, Cubans Face Stark Choice: ‘Prison or Exile’
item.description: Thousands of Cubans took to the streets last July protesting economic misery. A year later, hundreds are in jail and the financial crisis has only worsened.
item.dc:creator: Oscar Lopez
item.category: Human Rights and Human Rights Violations
item.media:description: Plainclothes police officers clashing with antigovernment protesters last July 11 in Havana during the biggest wave of demonstrations since the Communist government took power.

item.title: Three Cities in China Impose Partial Lockdowns and Macau Shuts Casinos
item.description: The cities of Xi’an, Lanzhou and Haikou set restrictions on several million residents. In Macau, the gambling hub, authorities shut casinos and ordered everyone to stay home.
item.dc:creator: Tiffany May and Zixu Wang
item.media:description: Coronavirus testing last week in Macau, whose 680,000 residents have been relatively sheltered from the virus.

item.title: Biden to Make First Visit as President to Israel and Saudi Arabia
item.description: On his first trip to the region since taking office, President Biden will begin in Israel, which has been building relations with Arab nations. He will also make a stop in Saudi Arabia.
item.dc:creator: Patrick Kingsley
item.media:description: President Biden arriving at Joint Base Andrews last Wednesday. During his trip to the Middle East, Mr. Biden is expected to discuss the emerging Arab-Israeli military partnership to combat threats from Iran.

item.title: Embattled Leaders in Hiding, Sri Lankans Ask: What’s Next?
item.description: Protesters in Sri Lanka roamed the halls and grounds of power without challenge as they waited to see who would take the reins of their economically devastated country.
item.dc:creator: Emily Schmall and Mujib Mashal
item.media:description: The garden of the presidential palace in Colombo on Sunday.

item.title: Your Tuesday Briefing
item.description: Russia’s strikes on Ukrainian civilians.
item.dc:creator: Natasha Frost
item.media:credit: Daniel Berehulak for The New York Times
item.media:description: Ukrainain soldiers salvaging parts from a Russian armoured vehicle. The British military recently estimated the number of dead Russians at 25,000.

item.title: Russia Steps Up Attacks on Civilian Areas, Even With Advance Paused
item.description: Russian forces in eastern Ukraine are regrouping, with a new offensive expected, but they continue to rain death and destruction on cities and towns.
item.dc:creator: Carlotta Gall, Kamila Hrabchuk and Matthew Mpoke Bigg
item.media:credit: Mauricio Lima for The New York Times
item.media:description: Residents tried to extinguish a fire minutes after rockets hit a residential area in Bakhmut on Sunday.

item.title: Russia Is Getting Iran to Send Hundreds of Drones, White House Says
item.description: The national security adviser said the U.S. believed Iran was preparing to train Russian troops imminently.
item.dc:creator: Eric Schmitt
item.media:description: Jake Sullivan, the national security adviser, said on Monday that Russia is seeking surveillance drones from Iran to use against Ukraine.

item.title: Your Tuesday Briefing: Bank Protests in China
item.description: Plus Ukrainian civilians bear the brunt of Russia’s war and new details after Shinzo Abe’s death.
item.dc:creator: Amelia Nierenberg
item.category: Far East, South and Southeast Asia and Pacific Areas

item.title: Webb Space Telescope: Biden and NASA Reveal First Image
item.description: From the White House on Monday, humanity got its first glimpse of what the observatory in space has been seeing: a cluster of early galaxies.
item.dc:creator: Dennis Overbye, Kenneth Chang and Jim Tankersley
item.media:description: The Webb telescope’s image of the galaxy cluster SMACS 0723 includes thousands of galaxies, including the faintest objects ever observed in infrared. The light from SMACS 0723 in this image is 4.6 billion years old.

item.title: Putin Extends Fast-Track Russian Citizenship Process to All Ukrainians
item.description: The move indicated that Russia might seek to establish permanent control of Ukrainian territories currently occupied by Moscow’s forces.
item.dc:creator: Ivan Nechepurenko
item.media:description: A Migration Service office offering Russian passports to local residents, in Donetsk, Ukraine, this month.

item.title: E.U. Health Agency Recommends Second Covid Booster for Older People
item.description: The recommendation came as fears rise over mounting cases and hospitalizations across Europe.
item.dc:creator: Euan Ward
item.media:credit: Dmitry Kostyukov for The New York Times
item.media:description: Crowds at the Trocadéro near the Eiffel Tower in Paris, in May.

item.title: Dueling Weaknesses
item.description: The Times has released its first poll of the 2022 midterm cycle.
item.dc:creator: David Leonhardt
item.media:description: President Biden after a trip to Cleveland last week.

item.title: A Glimpse Inside a Florentine Silk-Weaving Workshop
item.description: The Antico Setificio Fiorentino, which relies on looms from the 18th and 19th centuries, has been producing precious textiles since 1786.
item.dc:creator: Susan Wright

item.title: Your Monday Briefing
item.description: Russia seeks new soldiers.
item.dc:creator: Natasha Frost
item.media:credit: Daniel Berehulak for The New York Times
item.media:description: Ukrainain soldiers salvaging parts from a Russian armoured vehicle. The British military recently estimated the number of dead Russians at 25,000.

item.title: Brittney Griner Is Honored by Fellow Players at W.N.B.A. All-Star Game
item.description: The league made Griner, who has been detained in Russia since February, an honorary starter for the game.
item.dc:creator: Remy Tumin and Shauntel Lowe
item.media:description: The W.N.B.A. All-Stars wore matching jerseys with Brittney Griner’s number, 42, during the second half of the All-Star Game on Sunday.

item.title: War in Ukraine Could Have You Paying More For Hummus
item.description: Russia and Ukraine are two of the biggest exporters of chickpeas, and the global supply is expected to decline this year.
item.dc:creator: Maham Javaid
item.media:credit: Valaurian Waller for The New York Times
item.media:description: The global supply of chickpeas may be reduced by as much as 20 percent this year because Russia and Ukraine are two of the world’s biggest exporters of the legume, according to a trade group.

item.title: Your Monday Briefing: Sri Lanka in Turmoil
item.description: Plus Shinzo Abe’s allies win a supermajority in Japan’s parliament and Russia bombards Donetsk.
item.dc:creator: Amelia Nierenberg
item.category: Far East, South and Southeast Asia and Pacific Areas
item.media:description: Demonstrators protested inside the President’s House in Colombo, Sri Lanka, on Saturday.

item.title: A survivor emerges from the rubble of an apartment complex.
item.dc:creator: Carlotta Gall and Kamila Hrabchuk
item.media:credit: Mauricio Lima for The New York Times
item.media:description: Emergency crews working in Chasiv Yar, where Russian rockets struck an apartment complex.

item.title: In Ivory Coast, This Rainforest Is Both Refuge and Junkyard
item.description: An endangered gem of lush greenery in Abidjan, Ivory Coast’s economic hub, is at the center of government efforts to promote ecotourism. Those who live and work there worry about what it means for them.
item.media:credit: Andrew Caballero-Reynolds for The New York Times
item.media:description: A highway separates Banco National Park from the sprawl of Abidjan, the economic hub of Ivory Coast.

item.title: What We Know About the Protests in Sri Lanka
item.description: Months of demonstrations over dire economic conditions culminated in a peaceful takeover of the presidential residence and promises of resignations.
item.dc:creator: The New York Times
item.media:description: Protesters at the residence of President Gotabaya Rajapaksa of Sri Lanka in the capital, Colombo, on Saturday.

item.title: To Ease Germany’s Gas Crisis, Canada Will Return a Nord Stream 1 Turbine
item.description: The turbine — a critical piece of pipeline equipment — had been sent to Canada for repairs, but its return had been held up by sanctions against Russia.
item.dc:creator: Cassandra Vinograd
item.media:credit: Lena Mucha for The New York Times
item.media:description: Nord Stream 1 pipelines at a port in Lubmin, Germany, last year.

item.title: At Least 21 Dead After 3 Tavern Shootings in South Africa
item.description: The shootings further highlighted concerns about safety, coming only two weeks after 21 teenagers died mysteriously in a coastal city tavern.
item.dc:creator: Lynsey Chutel
item.media:description: A crowd gathered on Sunday as the police removed bodies from a township tavern in Soweto, Johannesburg, where a group of armed men had opened fire and then fled.

item.title: In Eastern Ukraine, Attacks Intensify as Russia Readies New Offensive
item.description: The civilian toll has risen sharply in recent days as rockets and shells strike residential areas in the likely path of Russia’s coming push into Donetsk Province.
item.dc:creator: Carlotta Gall
item.media:credit: Mauricio Lima for The New York Times
item.media:description: Rescuers at an apartment building struck by a Russian rocket in Chasiv Yar, Ukraine, had pulled five people from the rubble by midday Sunday, and recovered 15 bodies.

item.title: Shinzo Abe’s Party Triumphs in Parliamentary Vote, Extending Legacy
item.description: The Liberal Democrats and their partners gained enough seats to form a supermajority. They can now amend the country’s pacifist Constitution.
item.dc:creator: Motoko Rich
item.media:description: Voting in Tokyo on Sunday to fill seats in the Upper House of Japan’s Parliament. The governing Liberal Democrats are hoping for a supermajority.

item.title: The G.O.P.’s ‘Wildest Dream’
item.description: The election of Mayra Flores, a Republican and an immigrant, helps explain how Latino voters are shifting to the right.
item.dc:creator: Ian Prasad Philbrick
item.media:credit: Shuran Huang for The New York Times
item.media:description: Representative Mayra Flores of Texas with lawmakers and her daughters on the steps of the Capitol. She is the first Republican Latina the state has ever sent to Congress.

item.title: Sri Lankan Father Sees Protests As Education for His Children
item.description: Mohammad Imran’s children have barely attended school because of the nation’s economic crisis. And he says his salary barely covers the basics.
item.dc:creator: Emily Schmall
item.media:description: Mohammad Imran borrowed fuel from his nephew to take his children Barerah, 11, and Thameem, 5, to see the ransacked presidential mansion.

item.title: What We Know About the Shinzo Abe Assassination
item.description: The police in Nara, Japan, say a 41-year-old man was responsible for the fatal shooting of the former prime minister, but have given few details about the suspect.
item.dc:creator: David Moll
item.media:description: Former prime minister Shinzo Abe was shot on Friday while speaking in Nara, Japan. On Saturday locals lined up to leave memorial flowers near the site of the speech.

item.title: Sri Lankan Protesters Wander Halls After President Flees
item.description: Hours after protesters took control the building, it has effectively become a free museum. People stream in and admire the art as Army guards quietly patrol the halls.
item.dc:creator: Emily Schmall
item.media:description: The garden of the presidential palace in Colombo on Sunday.

item.title: Sri Lanka Needs Billions As It Exhausts Financing
item.description: Funds provided by India are already gone. China has kept its distance. As the crisis deepens, Sri Lanka has even turned to charities in Qatar for help.
item.dc:creator: Mujib Mashal
item.media:credit: Atul Loke for The New York Times
item.media:description: Sri Lankans in line for fuel in Colombo in May.

item.title: The president has not been heard from since protesters overran his residence, fueling questions about who is in charge.
item.dc:creator: Vivek Shankar and Mujib Mashal
item.media:description: President Gotabaya Rajapaksa’s whereabouts were unknown on Sunday.

item.title: Protesters in Sri Lanka Mark Takeover of President’s Residence
item.description: Images from Colombo showed demonstrators enjoying a rare moment of levity, after months of economic deprivation.
item.dc:creator: Emily Schmall and Austin Ramzy
item.media:description: Protesters enjoyed the pool at President Gotabaya Rajapaksa’s official residence in Colombo, Sri Lanka, on Saturday.

item.title: Desperate for Recruits, Russia Launches a ‘Stealth Mobilization’
item.description: Leery of a national draft for the Ukraine war, the Kremlin is offering cash bonuses and employing strong arm tactics.
item.dc:creator: Neil MacFarquhar
item.media:credit: Finbarr O'Reilly for The New York Times
item.media:description: The body of a Russian soldier outside a school destroyed by bombardment in the village of Vilkhivka, Ukraine. Russia is losing fighters almost as fast as they can be replaced.

item.title: What Sparked the Protests in Sri Lanka?
item.description: Acute shortages have meant that medicines can’t be transported and fresh produce from farms can’t make it to cities.
item.dc:creator: Karan Deep Singh
item.media:credit: Atul Loke for The New York Times
item.media:description: Sri Lanka’s government has asked Russia for help to import fuel into the country.

item.title: Blinken presses his Chinese counterpart about the war.
item.dc:creator: Michael Crowley, Steven Erlanger and Catherine Porter
item.media:description: Antony J. Blinken, the U.S. secretary of state, in Nusa Dua, Indonesia, on Saturday. He emphasized shared interests between the U.S. and China in more than five hours of talks with his Chinese counterpart.

item.title: Ukraine Fires Its Ambassador to Germany After Controversial Remarks
item.description: Andriy Melnyk, an outspoken advocate for weapons for Ukraine, denied the role of a Ukrainian nationalist leader in the Holocaust, stoking outrage in Germany.
item.dc:creator: Erika Solomon
item.media:description: Andriy Melnyk, Ukraine’s ambassador to Germany, during an event commemorating the defeat of Nazi Germany in World War II at Berlin’s Soviet War Memorial in May.

item.title: Sri Lanka’s Prime Minister to Resign Amid Protests
item.description: Ranil Wickremesinghe, who had been in office only since May, said he would resign.
item.dc:creator: Emily Schmall
item.media:description: Prime Minister Ranil Wickremesinghe in Colombo in May.

item.title: Who Are the Rajapaksas?
item.description: The Rajapaksas have cast a shadow over politics in Sri Lanka for much of the past two decades, and in recent years, they have increasingly run the government as a family business.
item.dc:creator: Mujib Mashal
item.media:description: Mahinda Rajapaksa and his brother Gotabaya Rajapaksa, in Colombo, Sri Lanka, in 2019.

item.title: Sri Lanka’s Leader Will Resign, Ally Says, After Protesters Storm Residence
item.description: President Gotabaya Rajapaksa will step down on Wednesday, according to the speaker of Parliament, amid fury over the economic crisis.
item.dc:creator: Skandha Gunasekara and Mujib Mashal
item.category: Human Rights and Human Rights Violations
item.media:description: Protesters at the residence of President Gotabaya Rajapaksa of Sri Lanka in the capital, Colombo, on Saturday.

item.title: After Brutal Assassination of Shinzo Abe, Japan Mourns and Carries On
item.description: A day after former Prime Minister Shinzo Abe’s killing, Japan, where gun violence of any kind is rare, was just beginning to process the shock.
item.dc:creator: Motoko Rich, Daisuke Wakabayashi, Hikari Hida and Hisako Ueno
item.media:description: A car believed to be carrying former Prime Minister Shinzo Abe’s body passed by onlookers near his residence in Tokyo on Saturday.

item.title: Luis Echeverría Alvarez, Former President of Mexico, Dies at 100
item.description: He had faced accusations that, as interior secretary, he was responsible for repressing protests before the 1968 Olympics that ended in a massacre.
item.dc:creator: Jonathan Kandell
item.media:description: Luis Echeverría Alvarez in 1969 as he accepted his party’s nomination for president. He steered the country on a left-wing course, but his tenure was shadowed by his role in a massacre at the Olympic Games.

item.title: How Mexico’s Top Justice Became an Abortion Rights Champion
item.description: Influenced by feminists close to him, the chief of the country’s Supreme Court helped pave the way for decriminalization of the procedure.
item.dc:creator: Natalie Kitroeff
item.media:credit: Lisette Poole for The New York Times
item.media:description: Arturo Zaldívar Lelo de Larrea, chief justice of the Mexican Supreme Court. He said he believes that calling abortion murder “dilutes the humanity of women in virtue of a religious belief.”

item.title: Hong Kong Pilots Restore a Memory on Wheels: A Vintage Double-Decker Bus
item.description: When the pandemic cut their flight hours, two pilots spent months and hundreds of thousands of dollars reviving a vehicle that reminded them of a happier time in Hong Kong.
item.dc:creator: Tiffany May
item.media:credit: Louise Delmotte for The New York Times
item.media:description: Luca Tong behind the wheel of his “hot dog” bus on the Wan Chai harbor promenade in Hong Kong in June. Vintage buses of this variety have not picked up passengers on the streets of Hong Kong for a decade.

item.title: Behind Russia’s ‘Pause’ in Ukraine, Signs of a Troubled Effort to Regroup
item.description: The weapons and personnel Russia may be turning to, analysts say, suggest that Moscow’s next assault may not be as fierce as it promised.
item.dc:creator: Erika Solomon
item.media:description: Rescuers combed through debris at the site where residential buildings were destroyed by a missile strike in Kharkiv, Ukraine, on Saturday.

item.title: Blinken Presses China’s Top Diplomat on Ukraine
item.description: At a G20 meeting, Secretary of State Antony J. Blinken sought to cool tensions with Beijing in an effort to further isolate Russia. He met resistance.
item.dc:creator: Michael Crowley, Steven Erlanger and Catherine Porter
item.media:description: Foreign Minister Wang Yi of China, left, and Secretary of State Antony J. Blinken on the Indonesian resort island of Bali on Saturday.

item.title: Suspect in Abe’s Killing Will Be Handed Over to Prosecutors on Sunday, Police Say
item.description: Tetsuya Yamagami, 41, is accused of killing Shinzo Abe, Japan’s former prime minister.
item.dc:creator: Daisuke Wakabayashi and Hisako Ueno
item.media:credit: The Asahi Shimbun via Getty Images
item.media:description: Police officers at the scene of Shinzo Abe’s killing in Nara, Japan.

item.title: President Defies Calls to Step Down, Despite Mounting Pressure
item.dc:creator: Skandha Gunasekara and Mujib Mashal
item.media:description: President Gotabaya Rajapaksa, second right, and Mahinda Rajapaksa, second left, in Kandy, Sri Lanka, in 2020.

item.title: Summer Travel, Made Easy
item.description: You need not travel far to experience the delights of summer.
item.dc:creator: Melissa Kirsch

item.title: Canada’s Slow and Troubled Path to Rapid Transit
item.description: Partnerships with the private sector were supposed to protect cities from cost overruns and delays. That hasn’t always worked out.
item.dc:creator: Ian Austen
item.media:description: After more than a decade of construction, a major intersection in Toronto remains a chasm from a light rail project.
